Although some will no doubt laugh, at Championship level, despite being utterly ungainly with the ball at his feet, Lloyd Doyley at his best was terrific defensively. Quick, great tackling and decent in the air for someone who isn't a giant. He also absolutely worked his arse off, and improved in leaps and bounds under Rodgers and Malky.

There was a college team who split their squad in two and had half training with and half without helmets. The without group used rugby tackling techniques, and had a much lower rate of concussions because they didn't take risks. I'll see if I can find it.
This article: http://mmqb.si.com/2014/12/04/helmetless-football-practice-university-of-new-hampshire As an aside, I did hear that scrum caps lead to more concussions at lower levels because they encourage risk taking

WRITING.TITLE: Ukraine Holocaust project "opens neglected chapter of history"

WRITING.TEXT: Long time focus on physical rather than technical attributes, particularly at a young age where those who're more physically developed can monster smaller players. Not enough high quality coaches (the difference in numbers between England Germany or France is waaaaaaaaay out of proportion) Also, England aren't *that* bad internationally. Although, yes, the Premier League is absurdly rich, the English tradition of more or less making around the 1/4 finals in the WC is more or less par given the population size.
it's a different way of recognising value in a contract really - but it certainly makes things more complicated, especially when their is mental 3 or 4 way trades line up.

It's not really that stupid a question. In short, I don't know. It's just always happened. I guess because it makes moving a player easier if he's (usually) the only one in the deal - correct me if I'm wrong, but American sportsmen don't get a huge say, generally, if their club wants to move them on?
As for the transfer window, it used to last all the way through to about April (in England at least) but I think it was introduced as a way of attempting to reduce clubs bringing in players at the last minute to attempt to win the league etc

WRITING.TEXT:
We couldn't get an agreement with Palace over price. We offered 500k in addition to the 500k we paid them on promotion, which they rejected. They accepted offers to 3.5mn from Bristol City QPR, but he turned them down because he wants to move to us. It's not clear if we've still got an offer on the table or not, and we're waiting for Palace to blink. He's out of contract in the summer.
I think we could find a use for him as back up in the middle three behind Deeney, but I'm not sure he's the priority he was. Plus we've got way too many non-HG players as it is.

Absolutely. The question for the Pozzos is do they aim to keep Watford in the Prem, and feed the cash to allow Udinese to go for Europe, or let us attempt to get to Europe and just keep Udinese afloat. I think you can make an argument that they're much more likely to be able to get into Europe from Serie A.
There's also the issue of whether or not the fact that Giampaolo is owner of Udinese Gino of Watford (formally) circumvents that rule. I'm not sure it does.

WRITING.TEXT: that was Scottish FA rules, I believe. Furthermore, Gianpaolo Pozzo formally owns us; his dad owns Udinese Granada, iirc.

Teams we hate in no particular order: QPR, Luton, Crystal Palace Players we love (retired): Luther Blissett (all time top scorer) Heidar Helgusson, Tommy Mooney, Nigel Gibbs, John Barnes Players we particularly love (still going): Lloyd Doyley, Troy Deeney, Tom Cleverley (might just be me) Fernando Forestieri, Craig Cathcart, Almen Abdi, Odion "Gooooooooooooal" Ighalo
All time greatest manager: Graham Taylor; took us from the fourth division (now league 2) to second in the first division (Premier League) in seven seasons; an FA Cup final; Europe. Came back 12 years later and took us from Division 2 (league 1) straight through to the Premier League; finally won at Wembley in the 98/99 Play Off Final.
History; we've only played in yellow since the 60s. Prior to that a variety of kits had been worn, including blue and black white (which was worn at the start of WW1; it's why the season's away shirt is black white stripes)
Previously known as: the blues (guess why) and the brewers (due to the clubs links with the now defunct Benskin's Brewery.
Great choice of team, fella.

WRITING.TEXT: Us and Luton. It's so petty that there's a genuine streak of nastiness. Particularly between the knuckledraggers on both sides. We'll not be playing them for a while, but when we do, I imagine there'll be alot of over time for Herts police.

A number of reasons: 1. No real expansionist aims 2. Although Blue Division soldiers had fought for Hitler, Spain never formally entered the war 3. In the context of growing distrust hostility with Russia, Franco's anti-communism was seen as a Very Good Thing. Especially as the Republican forces had been backed by Stalin which had facilitated the growth of the Spanish Communist Party during the Civil War.
edit: Source: memories from spending a year learning stuff from Dr Judith Keene @ Sydney Uni.
edit 2: Although not an academic source, Giles Tremlett's Ghosts of Spain is terrific on post war Spanish stuff http://www.amazon.co.uk/Ghosts-Spain-Travels-Through-Countrys/dp/0571279392
Winning the play off final at the real Wembley in 99 will essentially be unbeatable

The time, defending the near post, I blocked a shot between my legs (just below the sensitive bits) but it still went in.
Or the time, tracking my winger across goal I got to the ball first and blasted it into the top corner.
Or the time I got caught clearing the ball, chipped a bone in my ankle and cycled home on it as I didn't think it was that bad.
I know
